smithsonianmag.com  (WEB - en-US)

Smithsonian.com is the website for the Smithsonian Magazine. The site says Smithsonian.com and its sister magazine cover “the topics and subject matters researched, studied and exhibited by the Smithsonian Institution -- science, history, art, popular culture and innovation.”

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

The site is owned by the Smithsonian Institution, a national educational facility with 19 museums, nine research centers, and more than 180 affiliates around the world. William Allman, chief digital officer for Smithsonian Enterprises, the revenue-generating arm of the Smithsonian, manages the website and other digital efforts. Allman began his career as a journalist on Science 80, published by the  American Association for the Advancement of Science, and moved to U.S. News & World Report as a senior writer and editor specializing in science, technology, and health. The site is supported by advertising and magazine memberships.

Content

The website contains a mix of original web-only stories plus articles from the magazine. Brian Wolly, digital editor of Smithsonian.com, said in an email the site publishes 40-50 stories per week, plus 20 or so articles per month from the print edition. The website covers a broad range of topics including history, nature, hard science, travel, and innovation. A recent edition contained a cultural analysis of Mad Magazine and the late Stephen Hawking’s exhortation to humans to leave earth for new planets. Articles are well-written and lushly illustrated.

Credibility

Articles are sourced to leading researchers, and headlines match the content of articles.

Corrections are run with notes from the editor explaining what was corrected in the article.

Transparency

Editorial staff are listed on the site, and links are provided with contact information to reach writers. Advertising is clearly labeled.

History

The website has been around in various iterations since the early 2000s, editor Wolly said, but it began in earnest as a magazine site in 2006.
